Efficient synthesis of imine from alcohols and amines over different crystal structure MnOX catalysts Jun Bu a 1 Wenbin Wang a 1 Hepeng Zhang a b ⁎ Chen Wu a Baoliang Zhang a Yueling Cao a Fengtao Zhou a Qiuyu Zhang a Xin Zhang a a School of Science, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi’an, 710129, PR China School of Science Northwestern Polytechnical University Xi’an 710129 PR China b Research & Development Institute of Northwestern Polytechnical University in Shenzhen, Shenzhen 518057, PR China Research & Development Institute of Northwestern Polytechnical University in Shenzhen Shenzhen 518057 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: School of Science, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi’an, 710129, PR China. School of Science Northwestern Polytechnical University Xi’an 710129 PR China 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract The redox properties of different crystal structure MnO2 in organic reactions at low temperature of 60 °C were disclosed. Among the three crystal structures (α-, β- and γ-types), γ-MnO2 showed unusual high heterogeneous catalytic performance, reusability and stability for imine formation from benzyl alcohol and aniline under mild conditions. The yield of imine over γ-MnO2 reached up to 98.1% in 12 h under air atmosphere and its formation rate per surface area was 27.9 μmol h−1 m−2, and various imines could be obtained in excellent yield over γ-MnO2. Based on series of catalyst characterizations, it was found that the high activity of γ-MnO2 was mainly attributed to its high concentration of low-valence manganese ions. Furthermore, the catalytic mechanism was also disclosed. This research may have certain reference value for heterogeneous catalytic reactions by manganese. Keywords MnO2 Crystal structure Imine synthesis 1 Introduction In recent years there has been a rising demand for efficient synthetic process for imines [1]. Because imines are very versatile intermediates and are widely applied in the preparation of drugs, pesticides and other important intermediates of organic matter [2]. Traditionally, imines are synthesized via dehydrating condensation of amines with carbonyl compounds [3]. Recently, several alternative strategies to synthesize imines by the dimerization of primary amines [4–6], oxidation of secondary amines [7–9] have also been devoted. However, several drawbacks including the low efficiency for unsymmetric imines and the production of unwanted nitrile byproducts limit their applications. In contrast with traditional synthesis methods, the direct coupling of alcohols and amines is one of the most promising strategies [10–12], which has received lots of attention because of its advantages of cost effectiveness, low pollution, and non-toxic by-product (only water is produced). To date, various supported effective noble metal heterogeneous (Pd [13], Pt [14], Ru [1], and Au [15]) catalysts has been reported, yet these catalysts are based on noble metals and require high temperatures and pure O2. Among non-noble metal reaction system, MnO2 may be a good candidate for this reaction owing to their unique properties such as high catalytic reducibility, low cost, nontoxicity, and rich structures. However, Tumura and coworkers [12] found that MnO2 shows little catalytic activity for this reaction, Blackburn [16] reported that MnO2 has positive catalytic activity for the direct coupling of alcohol and amine, but large amounts of molecular sieves were used. In general, MnO2 is known as a non-stoichiometric compound and can exist in different structural forms, α-, β- and γ-types [17]. These structures vary in the way that MnO6 octahedra are interlinked, they possess tunnels or interlayers with gaps of different magnitudes. The properties of MnO2 are strongly related to its crystallographic structures [18–20], and based on this, MnO2 is widely used as electrode materials [21,22], ion-sieves [23–25], soft magnetic materials [26–28], and especially as catalysts [20,29,30]. Thus, it is meaningful to study the relation between structural forms of MnO2 and its catalytic activity for the imine formation from alcohols and amines, and the results will be highly valuable for further research, unfortunately, there has been no related researches about this until now. Herein, we investigated the catalytic performance of MnO2 with different crystallographic structures (α-, β- and γ-types) to the direct coupling of alcohol and amine for the first time. To our surprise, the yield of imine reached up to 98.1% in 12 h at 60 °C under atmosphere and its formation rate per surface area was 27.9 μmol h−1 m−2 when using γ-MnO2 as catalyst, to our knowledge, it is higher than many catalysts which had been reported (see Table S1). However, α-MnO2 (yield = 27.4%) and β-MnO2 (yield = 43.9%) show bad catalytic performance. XPS and H2-TPR analysis demonstrated that the high activity of γ-MnO2 is a result of its high concentration of low-valence manganese ions. The catalytic mechanism was also disclosed by DRIFTS. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparetion α-MnO2 was prepared by following the reported hydrothermal method [31]. In a typical synthesis, 10 mL of 1 M HCl aqueous solution was added into 20 mL of 1 M KMnO4 aqueous solution. After completely stirred, the reaction mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and kept at 150 °C for 6 h. After cooled to room temperature, the product was filtered, washed with distilled water and ethanol, dried at 80 °C for 6 h. The product was designed as α-MnO2. γ-MnO2 was prepared by a simple chemical precipitation method. In a typical synthesis procedure, 13.5 g Mn(NO)2·4H2O was dissolved into 80 mL distilled water and 50 mL isopropanol. The reaction mixture was heated to 80 °C for 30 min under continuous stirring. 50 mL aqueous solution of KMnO4 (0.36 M) was added drop-wise to the reaction mixture and kept for 30 min. After the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, the product was filtered with distilled water and ethanol, then dried at 80 °C for 24 h. β-MnO2 was obtained by the calcining of γ-MnO2 at 300 °C for 3 h. When the calcining temperature increased to 500 °C, Mn2O3 can be obtained. The products were designed as γ-MnO2, β-MnO2 (calcined at 300 °C) and Mn2O3 (calcined at 500 °C) respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on shimadzu XRD-600 X-ray diffractometer in the 2θ range of 5–80° with a scan speed of 2°/min. An X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiment was carried on a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD system at room temperature. The binding energy was normalized to signal for adventitious carbon at 284.6 eV [32]. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were recorded on a TriStar II 20 apparatus, and the specific surface area determination and pore volume analysis were performed by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods, respectively. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), O2 temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) experiments were performed on AutoChem II 2920 instrument fitted with TCD detector. In a typical H2-TPR experiment, a sample mass of ca. 100 mg was outgassed at 200 °C under an Argon flow (25 mL/min) and subsequently cooled to 40 °C. Then the temperature was raised to 500 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min using 10% H2 in Argon as the analytic gas, with a flow of 50 mL/min. The consumption of H2 was recorded by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). O2-TPD experiment was similar to H2-TPR, 20% O2 in Argon was used as the analytical gas. In a typical DRIFTS spectra were recorded with a Bruker Optics VERTEX 70 equipped with a liquid nitrogen-cooled MCT detector, using an in situ IR cell with CaF2 windows, which was connected to a conventional gas flow system. In a typical procedure: MnO2 (∼50 mg) was pretreated at 200 °C for 30 min in the in situ IR cell under N2. Then benzyl alcohol was injected into homemade vapor generator heated at 300 °C under N2 flow, which was fed to in situ IR cell. Then, IR measurement was carried out. After the spectra was stable, N2 was replaced by air flow, and the spectra change was monitored. When the spectra was stable again, aniline was introduced by the same method. 2.3 Catalytic performance Before we investigated MnO2 catalysts for the direct coupling of benzyl alcohol and aniline, we wanted to exclude the mass transfer limitation [33–36]. A Weisz-Prater analysis was made for internal diffusion. The Weisz-Prater criterion gave C wp = r o b s ρ c R p 2 D e f f C s = 3.37 × 10 − 7 < 1 , indicating internal diffusion can be eliminated (see the Supplementary information). In addition, the stirring rate was changed with γ-MnO2 as a model catalyst. Fig. S1 shows the plot of yield versus the stirring rate. With stirring rate increasing, the yield of imine increased and remained almost constant when the stirring rate reached 800 rpm. Therefore, the stirring rate was set at 1000 rpm in the following studies and the mass transfer limitation can be excluded. In a typical synthesis, benzyl alcohol (1 mmol), catalyst (50 mg), aniline (2 mmol), mesitylene (1.6 mL) were stirred with magnetic stirring at 1000 rpm at 60 °C under air. After reaction, the mixture was diluted with ethanol and centrifuged. Reactant conversion and product selectivity were determined based on benzyl alcohol using High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC). The purification of the product was performed by column chromatography on silica gel using hexane and diethyl ether (hexane/diethyl ether = 4/1) as eluent. To avoid the hydrolysis of the produced imine during the purification, the silica gel was washed by triethyl amine before the purification. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure analysis Four manganese oxides were sythensized in this article and their phase purity and crystal structures were determined by XRD, as shown in Fig. 1 . In the pattern of α-MnO2, all diffraction peaks can be indexed to a pure tetragonal phase of α-MnO2 (JCPDS no. 44-0141). The XRD pattern of γ-MnO2 synthesized by chemical precipitation method confirms the phase purity of γ-MnO2 ((JCPDS no. 14-0644). When the γ-MnO2 was calcined at 300 °C for 3 h, the XRD pattern of the resulting product matched well with β-MnO2 (JCPDS no. 24-0735). However, when the calcining temperature was increased to 500 °C, peaks of β-MnO2 disappeared and several new diffraction peaks emerged, which correspond to Mn2O3 (JCPDS no. 41-1442). Textural properties of catalysts were investigated by nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements (Fig. S2). All of them were type IV patterns according to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) classification, which confirms these MnO2 catalysts have a mesoporous structure. Such mesoporosity may greatly benefit the mass transfer, thereby enhancing the catalytic perfor mance of the manganese oxide. Additionally, all of manganese oxides, as shown in Table 1 , exhibit high BET surface area and the BET surface area decreases in the following order: γ-MnO2 (58.7 m2/g) < β-MnO2 (41.2 m2/g) < α-MnO2 (34.5 m2/g) < Mn2O3 (29.7 m2/g). To further confirm the morphologies of different crystal MnO2, SEM (Fig. 2 ) analysis were employed. It can be observed in Fig. 2a that α-MnO2 has a urchin-like structure, assembled by uniform nanorod with average diameter of about 180 nm and 2.1 μm in length (Fig. 2b), in contrast, Fig. 2c and d show that β-MnO2 is sphere-like microstructure with the diameter of about 145 nm, furthermore, it is clear that β-MnO2 forms by agglomeration of multiple nano-MnO2 monocrystals. γ-MnO2 shows the similar sphere-like sturcture with β-MnO2. Compared with γ-MnO2, most of Mn2O3 showed shorter rod-like structure. (Fig. 2g and h). 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic experiments were conducted to reveal the catalytic activity of the as-prepared α-, β-, γ-MnO2 and Mn2O3 for the direct coupling of alcohol and aniline, the results are shown in Fig. 3 a. The yield of imines over Mn2O3, α-MnO2 and β-MnO2 was found to be only 5.4%, 27.4% and 43.9% at 60 °C in 12 h. The use of γ-MnO2 led to a great increment with the imine yield of 98.1%, indicating that the as-prepared γ-MnO2 is highly active for the direct coupling of benzyl alcohol and aniline in atmospheric and facile operated reaction system. Furthermore, the apparent activation energy (Ea) for the reaction between benzyl alcohol and aniline over the three MnO2 catalysts were also calculated (Fig. 3b). Among various MnO2 catalysts, γ-MnO2 possess the lowest Ea value (55 kJ/mol), which is consistent with its catalytic activity. Based on aforementioned results, it could be found that γ-MnO2 catalyst already appears as quite a unique and interesting material. Next, a series of characterizations were performed to explain the catalytic performance difference of various manganese oxides in the direct coupling of alcohol and aniline. 3.3 The relationship between catalytic performance and surface properties It’s well known that the redox property of metal oxides is highly related to their oxygen vacancy fractions [37–39]. Therefore, to get insight into the relationships between catalytic performance and surface chemical state of various MnO2, XPS analysis of the three MnO2 were measured and the patterns were shown in Fig. 4 . By performing peak-fitting deconvolutions, the Mn 2p3/2 spectra can be divided into two characteristic peaks with binding energy at 641.9 and 643.0 eV corresponding to surface Mn3+ and Mn4+ species [40–42], respectively (Fig. 4a). According to the fitted area of Mn 2p, the ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ on the surface decreased in following order (Table 1): γ-MnO2 (1.04) < β-MnO2 (0.56) < α-MnO2 (0.47), which is in line with their catalytic activity trend. Generally, surface Mn3+ species along with labile lattice oxygen were found to play important roles in promoting the catalytic activity for the cross-coupling of alcohols with amines [10]. O2 could be adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies of manganese oxides, and subsequently reduced by two electrons from the reduced Mnx+ [29]. All the O 1s spectrum of the three MnO2 were also fitted into three peaks at 529.5, 531.6, 533.3 eV (Fig. 4c), these bands were assigned to lattice oxygen for Mn-O (denoted as Oα), the defect oxide or a hydroxyl-like group surface adsorbed oxygen (denoted as Oβ) and adsorbed molecular water (denoted as Oγ), respectively [43]. As expected, the change trend of the of Oβ concentration in various MnO2 samples was same as that of surface Mn3+ content, indicating a larger amount of defect oxide or a hydroxyl-like group existed on γ-MnO2 (Table 1). The above result was further confirmed by the average oxidation state (AOS) of Mn. The AOS decreased in the order of α-MnO2 (3.60) > β-MnO2 > (3.56) > γ-MnO2 (3.52), which was calculated according to the formula: AOS = 8.956 - 1.126ΔEs [44], where ΔEs was the difference of binding energy between Mn 3 s doublet peaks (Fig. 4b). To make a comparison, the XPS spectra and results of Mn2O3 was shown in Fig. S3 and Table S2. As expected, the ratio of Mn3+ of Mn2O3 was the highest in the four catalysts, and the ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ on the surface was 2.70. However, the content of Oβ (0.31) was the lowest among the as-prepared catalysts, which was consistent with the catalytic performance. Whereas, as for MnO2, the higher ratio of Mn3+ means a higher content of oxygen vacancies, which play vital roles for oxidation reactions [45]. According to the above discussion, it could be, therefore, concluded that the superior catalytic activity of γ-MnO2 toward the direct coupling of alcohol and aniline might mainly result from its high concentration of Mn3+ which was greatly associated with oxygen vacancies. (Fig. 4d). In addition, high proportion of surface Mn3+ ions implies that the redox potential between Mn4+ and Mn3+ cations is easier [46], which endows γ-MnO2 with the highest surface oxygen storage capacity (OSC) among the three MnO2 and Mn2O3. This view can be supported by the analysis of H2-TPR and O2-TPD. H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 a, two peaks of H2 consumption can be observed on all the curves. The lower temperature peak could be attributed to the consumptions of the absorbed oxygen series on their surface and the reduction process: Mn4+ to Mn3+ and Mn3+ to Mn2+, whereas the higher temperature peak can be assigned to the reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+ [45], which can also be confirmed by the XRD pattern of the products (Fig. S4). Considering the temperature and intensity of the first H2 consumption (Table 2 ), the OSC and reducibility of the samples decreases in the order of γ-MnO2>β-MnO2>α-MnO2>Mn2O3, and this agrees well with the order of catalytic activity. In addition, O2-TPD was conducted to investigate the release of the lattice oxygen. As can be seen in Fig. 5b, except for Mn2O3, two peaks can be found in all three MnO2 and the first desorption of oxygen was related to the desorption of surface lattice oxygen while the second peak attributed to the release of bulk lattice oxygen [47]. Among them, the surface lattice oxygen desorption temperature of γ-MnO2 is 447 °C, lower than α-MnO2 (529 °C) and β-MnO2 (458 °C) respectively, consistent with the result of H2-TPR. Mn2O3 has almost no peaks of surface lattice oxygen desorption and the release temperature of bulk lattice oxygen is 764 °C, the highest in all the four catalysts. These results confirmed that γ-MnO2 hold the highest oxygen mobility and OSC, and this enormously improved its catalytic activity. In general, as the increase of the content of Mn3+ on the surface of MnO2, the OSC, oxygen vacancy defects(OVD), defect oxide or a hydroxyl-like group all increased, as shown in Fig. 6 , and these enhanced the catalytic activity toward the direct coupling of alcohol and aniline. Then, one important conclusion could be obtained that the primary influence factor to the catalytic activity was the concentration of Mn3+ on the surface of MnO2. When the stoichiometric ratio between Mn and O was about 1:2, higher concentration of Mn3+ on the surface means higher concentration oxygen vacancy and stronger lattice oxygen mobility. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism The time course of imine synthesis over γ-MnO2 at 60 °C was performed to investigate the process of the reaction (Fig. 7 ). During this reaction, the selectivity to imine kept in a high level and the yield to imine reached up to 98.1% with 99% selectivity in 12 h. Little benzaldehyde can be observed at the initial stage and the amount of benzaldehyde decreased slowly with the reaction proceeding, indicating that the benzaldehyde is an intermediate and thus, it can be speculated that the reaction proceeds by two consecutive steps (Scheme 1 ), the formation of benzaldehyde from benzyl alcohol and the further reaction of benzaldehyde with aniline to obtain imine, which is similar to the conclusion reported by Tamura and co-workers [12]. Furthermore, the oxidation of benzyl alcohol was performed over γ-MnO2 under the same condition (60 °C, air balloon, 12 h, without the addition of aniline), the conversion of benzyl alcohol was 63% and the selectivity of benzaldehyde was 100%, suggesting that the addition of aniline accelerated the oxidation of benzyl alcohol. The direct reactions between benzaldehyde and aniline were also carried with and without catalyst, and the conversions of benzaldehyde were 98.3% and 93.6% respectively. These implied that catalyst mainly accelerated the oxidation of benzyl alcohol. To further clarify the mechanism of this reaction, the reaction process was investigated by DRIFTS. γ-MnO2 (∼50 mg) was pretreated at 200 °C under N2 to remove surface H2O and CO2, then the temperature of the cell decreased to 60 °C under N2. Benzyl alcohol (5 μL) was injected into the cell and adsorbed on the surface of γ-MnO2, followed by the introduction of air, then aniline, the results were shown in Fig. 8 . Five bands at 1373, 1452, 1486, 1591 and 1696 cm−1 can be detected as soon as introduction of benzyl alcohol on MnO2. Band at 1373 cm−1 is assigned to δ(OH) vibration of benzyl alcohol and bands at 1452, 1486 and 1591 cm−1 correspond to CC stretching vibrations of the benzene ring. Peak at 1696 cm−1 can be assigned to υ(CO) vibration of benzaldehyde [48,49]. As above, a part of benzyl alcohol was transformed into benzaldehyde under N2 flow at 60 °C, indicating that benzyl alcohol reacted with MnO2 to form benzaldehyde. In addition, the introduction of air promoted the formation of benzaldehyde from adsorbed benzyl alcohol on MnO2, indicating that selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde was advanced by O2 and MnO2. At the end of air introduction, benzyl alcohol was completely converted and a new band at 1400 cm−1 appeared. This band can be assigned to CO symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate adspecies [50]. These carboxylate adspecies were produced by the adsorption of benzaldehyde. Benzaldehyde and carboxylate adspecies almost disappeared as soon as introduction of aniline, and new band at 1624 cm−1 appeared immediately. This band can be assigned to υ(CN) of imines. This result also indicated that the introduced aniline could react with benzaldehyde rapidly. From all the above results and discussions, the possible catalytic mechanism of imine formation from benzyl alcohol and aniline over MnO2 proceeds by two steps (Scheme 2 ): the first step is the oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde, It proceeds in the following sequence (Scheme 3 ): 1) the adsorption of benzyl alcohol on MnO2 to form corresponding alkoxide, 2) α-H activation of alkoxide species by surface adsorbed oxygen to form the carbonyl compound, 3) the electron transfer from carbonyl compound to Mn species accompanied by the benzaldehyde desorption, 4) the oxidation of Mn2+ by surface adsorbed oxygen with the desorption of water and the replenishment of surface adsorbed oxygen by air. The imine is formed by the further reaction of the produced benzaldehyde with aniline over MnO2. Thus, the reducibility of MnO2 plays an important role in the oxidation of benzyl alcohols. On the other hand, the oxygen adsorbed on the surface of MnO2 may promote this process, which is consistent with former research [29]. 3.5 Reusability and stability Two major problems associated with heterogeneous catalysts are catalyst deactivation and the leaching of active species. Hence, recycling catalytic experiments were conducted to investigate the stability of the γ-MnO2. The results are shown in Fig. 9 . γ-MnO2 exhibited an excellent stability, and even in the fifth cycle, the yield toward imine was still over 96%, indicating that γ-MnO2 could well resist deactivation and leaching of active species. Importantly, when various primary alcohols and amines were used as substrates, γ-MnO2 still gave high activities and yields (Table 3 ). Alcohol derivatives bearing an electron-donating or -withdrawing group were also reacted efficiently with aniline to afford the desired amines in great yields (entry 3–6). The conversion of o-methyl benzyl alcohol could be transformed into the desired imines in excellent yields, indicating steric hindrance of methyl group at the o-position had little effect on the reaction. The reaction also proceeded successfully with 2-Thiophenemethanol, and gave 98% yield of the product (entry 7). Both electron-rich (p-Me, and o-Me) and electron-deficient (p-Cl) anilines reacted with benzyl alcohol to afford the corresponding imines in high yields (entry 1–2). Similarly, the steric hindrance of methyl group at the o-position had little impact on the activity of the reaction. 4 Conclusions In summary, the catalytic performance of MnO2 with different structural forms, α-, β- and γ-types for the direct coupling of benzyl alcohol and aniline was investigated. Among these catalysts, γ-MnO2 exhibited excellent catalytic performance and stability. Based on the analysis of H2-TPR, XPS, O2-TPD and pyridine-TPD and DRIFTS, the high activity can be attributed to its high concentration of Mn3+ on the surface of MnO2. As the enhancement of the concentration of Mn3+, the OSC, OVD, defect oxide or a hydroxyl-like group and acidic site are all increased, and these are benefit to the catalytic activity toward the direct coupling of alcohol and aniline. These results could lead to a new application of MnO2 in organic synthesis. Furthermore, this research may offer great opportunities for improving the synthesis of imines over manganese-based materials. coredata.dc:description: The redox properties of different crystal structure MnO2 in organic reactions at low temperature of 60 °C were disclosed. Among the three crystal structures (α-, β- and γ-types), γ-MnO2 showed unusual high heterogeneous catalytic performance, reusability and stability for imine formation from benzyl alcohol and aniline under mild conditions. The yield of imine over γ-MnO2 reached up to 98.1% in 12 h under air atmosphere and its formation rate per surface area was 27.9 μmol h−1 m−2, and various imines could be obtained in excellent yield over γ-MnO2. Based on series of catalyst characterizations, it was found that the high activity of γ-MnO2 was mainly attributed to its high concentration of low-valence manganese ions. Furthermore, the catalytic mechanism was also disclosed. This research may have certain reference value for heterogeneous catalytic reactions by manganese.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient synthesis of imine from alcohols and amines over different crystal structure MnOX catalysts
